skill.name: create-worktree-skill
skill.description: Use when the user explicitly asks for a SKILL to create a worktree. If the user does not mention "skill" or explicitly request skill invocation, do NOT trigger this. Only use when user says things like "use a skill to create a worktree" or "invoke the worktree skill". Creates isolated git worktrees with parallel-running configuration.
skill.summary: Use when the user explicitly asks for a SKILL to create a worktree. If the user does not mention "sk...
skill.author: EGAdams

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill with no executable code. All 23 static findings are false positives: markdown code blocks misidentified as backtick execution, YAML frontmatter as hidden file access, and the word 'prompt' misclassified as cryptographic content. The skill safely delegates worktree creation to the slash command.

content.user_title: Create git worktrees for parallel development
content.value_statement: Managing multiple branches requires switching contexts and rebuilding environments. This skill automates git worktree creation with isolated ports and configuration for running parallel development instances simultaneously.
actual_capabilities: Parses user requests to extract branch names and port offsets
Invokes slash command for automated worktree creation
Calculates unique port assignments to avoid conflicts
Sets up isolated environment configurations for each worktree
limitations: Requires the /create_worktree_prompt slash command to be available
Cannot create worktrees without a specified branch name
Port offsets must be integers if manually specified
Existing port conflicts are handled by the underlying command, not this skill

use_cases.title: Parallel feature work
use_cases.description: Work on multiple features simultaneously without context switching between branches

use_cases.title: Isolated testing
use_cases.description: Test changes in isolated environments without affecting the main development setup

use_cases.title: Version comparison
use_cases.description: Run and compare different branch versions side by side for release validation

prompt_templates.title: Simple worktree
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a worktree for the [branch-name] branch

prompt_templates.title: With port offset
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a worktree for [branch-name] with port offset [number]

prompt_templates.title: Isolated testing
prompt_templates.prompt: Set up a parallel environment on branch [branch-name] for isolated testing

output_examples.input: Create a worktree for the feature-auth branch
Create a worktree for hotfix-bug with port offset 3

best_practices: Use descriptive branch names that indicate the feature or fix being developed
Start with port offset 1 and increment for each additional concurrent worktree
Document which ports each worktree uses to avoid confusion
anti_patterns: Creating worktrees without a clear branch name in the request
Using the same port offset for multiple concurrent worktrees
Running worktrees without tracking which branches they represent

faq.question: What is a git worktree?
faq.answer: A git worktree allows you to have multiple working trees attached to the same repository, so you can work on multiple branches simultaneously without stashing changes.

faq.question: How many worktrees can I create?
faq.answer: You can create as many worktrees as your system resources support. Each worktree requires ports and memory. Most systems handle 3-5 concurrent worktrees comfortably.

faq.question: Does this skill modify my main repository?
faq.answer: No. The skill creates worktrees in a trees/ subdirectory. Your main working directory remains unchanged and unaffected by worktree operations.

faq.question: Is my data safe in worktrees?
faq.answer: Yes. Worktrees are full copies of the repository state. Changes in worktrees are isolated and do not affect each other or the main branch until merged.

faq.question: Why am I getting port conflicts?
faq.answer: Port conflicts occur when two processes use the same port. The slash command automatically kills existing processes on conflicting ports. Use unique port offsets for each worktree.

faq.question: How is this different from switching branches?
faq.answer: Branch switching requires stashing or committing changes. Worktrees let you have multiple branches checked out simultaneously, preserving all uncommitted changes in each worktree.
